title: Research Notes on O. O. Howard

description: Anne Richardson was a screen writer, known for her dedication to Oregon's documentary film industry, animation and history. She and her husband, Dennis Nyback, founded the Oregon Cartoon Institute in 2007. Anne also originated the Oregon Film History Conference in 2015. Born in 1954, she never graduated from either high school or undergraduate college, but talked her way into Columbia's MFA program and graduated with her first degree. She became obsessed with General Howard. She originally intended to write a filmscript on the Nez Perce War, but instead decided to explore developing a book or an exhibit. She never finished this project but left behind her notes, her theories about Howard's relationships with both Generals Sherman and Grant (which seem to be quite different from those of other writers), and the approach she would take. She died in 2020. Her notes roughly fit into 6 cateogries. Her notes on: 1. How she became interested in the Nez Perce and in OO Howard; 2. Her attempts to obtain funding for the project; 3. Her thougts on how she would write about the Nez Perce and the war of 1877; 4. Her thoughts and writings about OO Howard in particular; 5. title: Snake River Dams
creator: Shannon Wheeler
description: Join Shannon Wheeler, newly elected Chair, Nez Perce Tribe, and Kyle Smith, Snake River Director for American Rivers for a presentation at the Josephy Center about the Snake River Dams. Conversations around restoring the lower Snake River have been gaining momentum in recent months. Rep. Mike Simpson (R-ID), Washington Senator Patty Murray, Washington Governor Jay Inslee, the American Fisheries Society, and President Biden and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration have all suggested that removing the lower four Snake River dams could be part of a comprehensive plan to save Snake River salmon and steelhead. But the conversation is a controversial one---Would breaching the dams ensure fish populations recover? How long would it take for the dams to be breached? What would happen to the industries and communities that rely on the energy, transportation, and irrigation services the dams provide? What would dam removal mean for northeast Oregon? A live presentation at the Josephy Center for Arts and Culture.
